content.title: Hemolytic Anemia Overview
content.summary: Hemolytic anemias are characterized by premature destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis) faster than bone marrow can compensate. They are classified by mechanism (intrinsic vs extrinsic), location (intravascular vs extravascular), and etiology (inherited vs acquired). Key diagnostic features include reticulocytosis, elevated LDH and indirect bilirubin, decreased haptoglobin, and specific smear findings.
key_points: Intravascular hemolysis: Free Hb, hemoglobinuria, low haptoglobin
Intrinsic defects: Membrane (spherocytosis), enzyme (G6PD), hemoglobin (sickle cell)
LDH elevated, indirect bilirubin elevated, haptoglobin low/absent
content.statement: Hemolytic anemia results from accelerated red blood cell destruction exceeding bone marrow compensatory capacity, diagnosed by reticulocytosis and hemolysis markers, with classification and treatment determined by the underlying mechanism.

explanation.intuition: Think of RBCs as cars with a 120-day warranty. In hemolytic anemia, cars are being totaled before their time - either due to manufacturing defects (intrinsic) or road hazards (extrinsic). The factory (bone marrow) works overtime, producing young cars (reticulocytes) to compensate.
explanation.key_insight: The distinction between intravascular and extravascular hemolysis is crucial: Intravascular releases free hemoglobin into blood (hemoglobinuria, low haptoglobin), while extravascular occurs in spleen/liver (splenomegaly, jaundice). This distinction guides diagnosis and management.
explanation.technical_details: Haptoglobin irreversibly binds free hemoglobin and is consumed in intravascular hemolysis. LDH is released from lysed RBCs. Unconjugated bilirubin rises from heme catabolism. Reticulocyte production index >2 indicates appropriate marrow response.

definitions_glossary.hemolysis: Premature destruction of red blood cells before normal 120-day lifespan
definitions_glossary.intravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction within blood vessels with release of free hemoglobin
definitions_glossary.extravascular_hemolysis: RBC destruction in reticuloendothelial system (spleen, liver)
definitions_glossary.reticulocyte: Immature RBC recently released from bone marrow; elevated in hemolysis
definitions_glossary.haptoglobin: Plasma protein that binds free hemoglobin; consumed in intravascular hemolysis
definitions_glossary.indirect_bilirubin: Unconjugated bilirubin from heme degradation; elevated in hemolysis
definitions_glossary.LDH: Lactate dehydrogenase released from lysed RBCs; nonspecific but sensitive marker
definitions_glossary.spherocyte: Small, dense, spherical RBC without central pallor; seen in hereditary spherocytosis and AIHA
definitions_glossary.Coombs_test: Direct antiglobulin test detecting antibodies/complement on RBC surface
definitions_glossary.hemoglobinuria: Free hemoglobin in urine causing dark red/brown color
definitions_glossary.reticulocyte_production_index: Corrected reticulocyte count adjusting for anemia; RPI >2 = adequate response

pathophysiology.mechanism: Accelerated RBC destruction with compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia

differential_diagnosis: Non-hemolytic causes of reticulocytosis (bleeding, recovery from anemia)
Non-hemolytic causes of jaundice (Gilbert syndrome, liver disease)
Non-hemolytic elevated LDH (MI, lymphoma, lung disease)

supportive: Transfusion for severe anemia (use extended-match blood in AIHA)

definition.@value: A group of anemias caused by premature destruction of red blood cells, characterized by reticulocytosis and markers of hemolysis including elevated LDH, indirect bilirubin, and decreased haptoglobin

scopeNote.@value: Overview concept covering classification, diagnosis, and management principles applicable to all hemolytic anemias

learning_objectives: Classify hemolytic anemias by mechanism, location, and etiology
Distinguish intravascular from extravascular hemolysis clinically
Interpret peripheral smear findings to narrow hemolytic anemia differential
Select appropriate confirmatory tests based on clinical presentation
clinical_pearls: Spherocytes + positive Coombs = warm AIHA; spherocytes + negative Coombs = hereditary spherocytosis
Schistocytes + thrombocytopenia = MAHA (think TTP, HUS, DIC)
Reticulocyte production index >2 indicates adequate bone marrow response
G6PD levels may be falsely normal during acute hemolysis - repeat in 2-3 months
common_misconceptions: All hemolysis causes hemoglobinuria - only intravascular hemolysis does
Low haptoglobin is diagnostic of hemolysis - can also be low in liver disease or congenital absence
Reticulocyte count alone indicates hemolysis - need to calculate production index
